title: Specialized limited-edition “Manx Missile” bike honours Mark Cavendish’s green jersey and 34 stage wins
content:
Specialized has announced it will be releasing a special-edition S-Works Tarmac SL7 designed to celebrate Mark Cavendish’s achievements at the 2021 Tour de France.

Cavendish’s comeback Tour saw the 36-year-old win four stages and the green jersey, having previously won the points classification in 2011.

Called the “Manx Missle” (a nod to Cavendish’s nickname), the bike will be limited to only 34 frames – the number of stages Cavendish has now won across his career at the Tour de France, putting the sprinter in joint first position with Eddy Merckx for the most stages won by a rider at the race. 

The bike frames are each individually numbered and painted in different shades of green using a camouflage-like pattern, similar to other Specialized bikes of recent years.

Specialized says the bikes have been “created as a celebration of overcoming those who doubt us” and have “Lead the Change” written on the seat tube, which “challenges us all to fight for equality on and off the bike”.

The bike will come with Roval Rapide CLX wheels, featuring white graphics usually reserved for the pros, and Specialized Turbo Cotton clincher tyres. 

Cavendish rode every stage of this year’s Tour de France on clincher tyres. While many pros and teams continue to stick to tubular tyres, Deceuninck-Quickstep has been racing more and more on clinchers, with Specialized claiming the combination of its Roval clincher wheels and Turbo Cotton tyres is the fastest all-around setup. It’s something we previously discussed when looking at Kasper Asgreen’s Tour of Flanders bike.  

The Manx Missile bike also comes with Specialized Body Geometry finishing kit, including the S-Works Power with Mirror saddle and S-Works Ares shoes.

The Manx Missile package is completed with a signed Mark Cavendish print.

Specialized says the sale of each package will help to support Outride, an organisation that aims to empower communities by launching youth cycling initiatives. 

One of cycling’s greatest comeback stories

Tim de Waele / Getty Images

If anyone had said that Mark Cavendish would win four stages and the green jersey competition at the 2021 Tour de France, it is likely no one would have believed them. 

After a turbulent few years for the Manxman and a long recovery from illness, Cavendish showed great form in the lead up to the race, winning four stages of the Tour of Turkey and a stage of the Baloise Belgium Tour, but he wasn’t even selected for this year’s edition until a week before the Grand Départ.

However, Cavendish got the nod for Deceuninck-QuickStep’s squad due to an injury to Sam Bennett, the previous green jersey holder.

Tim de Waele / Getty Images

Then a whirlwind of a Tour, which saw Caleb Ewan crash out and Peter Sagan leave the race due to a knee injury, combined with the irrefutable power and skill of Deceuninck-QuickStep and the ambition that marks Cavendish as one of the best, created the perfect storm for Cavendish to claim the victories he did.

Cavendish also claims switching back to a Specialized bike has been a factor in his success. 

Tim de Waele / Getty Images

“I couldn’t get properly comfortable on a bike since I’ve left Specialized,” said Cavendish. “People thought I was crazy, but I just knew that if I could get back on a Specialized it would make a difference.”

Regardless of whether the Tarmac made a difference or it’s down to the rider piloting it and his Deceuninck-QuickStep lead out, Cavendish’s comeback has proved to be one of the sport’s greatest stories.
author: Stan Portus
